1: <sup>1</sup> The song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
2: <sup>2</sup> Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth: for thy love is better than wine.
3: <sup>3</sup> Because of the savour of thy good ointments thy name is as ointment poured forth, therefore do the virgins love thee.
4: <sup>4</sup> Draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his chambers: we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine: the upright love thee.
5: <sup>5</sup> I am black, but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.
6: <sup>6</sup> Look not upon me, because I am black, because the sun hath looked upon me: my mother’s children were angry with me; they made me the keeper of the vineyards; but mine own vineyard have I not kept.
7: <sup>7</sup> Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth, where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon: for why should I be as one that turneth aside by the flocks of thy companions?
8: <sup>8</sup> If thou know not, O thou fairest among women, go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock, and feed thy kids beside the shepherds’ tents.
9: <sup>9</sup> I have compared thee, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaoh’s chariots.
10: <sup>10</sup> Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.
11: <sup>11</sup> We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.
12: <sup>12</sup> While the king sitteth at his table, my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.
13: <sup>13</sup> A bundle of myrrh is my well-beloved unto me; he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts.
14: <sup>14</sup> My beloved is unto me as a cluster of camphire in the vineyards of Engedi.
15: <sup>15</sup> Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves’ eyes.
16: <sup>16</sup> Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant: also our bed is green.
17: <sup>17</sup> The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters of fir.
